candidates.title: deps: use sha1 crate instead of the deprecated sha-1 crate
Bump sctp-proto to 0.2.2
candidates.body: Another bump moving some logging from debug to trace in sctp crate

candidates.title: Update sctp-proto for panic fix
candidates.body:
Found a bug in sctp-proto: https://github.com/webrtc-rs/sctp-proto/issues/8

It's fixed so let's update.

candidates.title: Update sctp-protocol to 0.1.7
candidates.body: Improves data channels on lossy connections

candidates.title: Refactor openssl to crypto
candidates.body:
- Reword expect
- Remove `ToRtpIv` trait for `aes_128_cm_sha1_80`
- Remove `ToRtpIv` trait for `aead_aes_128_gcm`
- Move `KeyingMaterial` out of ossl module
- Add CI check for `--no-default-features`
- crypto.rs -> crypto/mod.rs
- Refactor OpenSSL DTLS into crypto mod
- Feature gate openssl
- Move things around in crypto
- Refactor our SRTP crypto
- Feature gate all openssl

candidates.title: feat: always use `sha1` crate for sha1-hmac
candidates.body:
Currently, `openssl` is used to perform SHA1-HMAC on Windows. The module's comment states that `sha1-asm` does not work on Windows which is true. It would only work on the `windows-gnu` toolchain but that one breaks `openssl`. If https://github.com/RustCrypto/asm-hashes/issues/45 were resolved, we could also compile `sha1` asm on `windows-msvc`.

Simply disabling the `asm` feature on Windows seems to be the best trade-off. This makes things slower on Windows.

As part of this refactoring, I designed the new `sha1-hmac` functionality to be stateless which ended up deleting the `RtpHmac` trait. This trait was only implemented on one type which suggests that it wasn't a very good use of a `trait` anyway.

This is the first step in making the `openssl` dependency optional as discussed in https://github.com/algesten/str0m/issues/413.

candidates.title: Feature _internal_test_exports for tests and fuzz
candidates.body: The feature `_internal_test_exports` enables code that is used for integration tests and fuzzing. This PR also makes `pub(crate)` of a bunch of `fn`s that were `#[doc(hidden)]`. That might break someone's code downstream, but we want to at least have code documentation on which functions are de-facto public API (or consider making them proper public API).

candidates.title: Allow low-level access to `IceAgent`, `IceAgentEvent` & `StunMessage` via `ice` module
candidates.body: In order to allow low level access to `ice` in a similar way as `rtp`, we introduce a public `ice` module that rexports `IceAgent` and `IceAgentEvent`. In addition, we also export `StunMessage` publicly from the `ice` module. To keep the public API small, all functions apart from `StunMessage::parse` are marked as `pub(crate)`. For standalone usage of `IceAgent`, we only need to be able to parse `StunMessage`s but not expose any other details.
